This video blew my mind, specifically the part where you touch the subject of polarization. I’ve been thinking about the consequences of it on many different aspects of our society. And I may be wrong, but it seems to me like the pattern and consequences are the same (yelling), no matter what the subject in discussion is. I’m an information tech at an university in Orlando FL, and my job is to find solutions. (that’s a very simplistic way of describing an IT) So in the back of my mind, not very actively, I’ve been trying to find a solution to polarization, as I’ve noticed traces of it all over our life. For example; I’ve noticed polarization on marital arguments, administrative discussions, professional expertise, faith based arguments and of course on political perspectives.
Now, four years later, it is impossible not to see the polarization gap has grown bigger by a lot at the political level, and as a result the yelling also has increased. And I still haven’t found a tangible solution.
What makes it interesting is, that to my understanding, the polarization is a collective behavior, and the solution seems to be an individual behavior. So to establish a perspective you listen to different collective opinions but to establish a wise conclusion, the decision has to be made in a personal level.
Making that balance between collectives opinions and a personal conclusion seems to be against our human nature, since we are social entities. I’ve also noticed that those social groups with different opinions tend to reject those who dare to listen to the other group’s perspectives. Such behavior from our society makes it more difficult to gather information from different points of the spectrum.
Education would be a nice starting point. But it feels like it isn’t always a convenient solution. Specifically for those providing the information, since by nature we want others to share our same opinion. So an open discussion would be an open door for others to flip sides. So we tend to control open discussions to our convenience.
In essence, I believe polarization is here to stay. We just have to learn to deal with it. Education and the ability to make a personal conclusion are key factors.
But I want to thank you for bringing up such a perspective on your video and provoking our thoughts.

in engineering control theory, there’s something called a “feedback loop.” there’s positive feedback and negative feedback. if you remove negative feedback from any system, it almost always goes divergent and chaotic. this is not political science, this is math. when people on the left or the right only listen to the media that agrees with their way of thinking, that’s a dangerous situation. if there’s no negative feedback pulling you towards the center, you’re going to drift out closer to the extremes … its a responsibility of everybody on both sides of the political [divide] to listen to both sides of the argument. if not, you’re going to be in an echo chamber that only amplifies those voices that you want to hear, and pretty soon there’s nothing but yelling.

Hey Destin. I'm a student  from Western Michigan University double majoring in both Engineering and Communications. What you are talking about is a mix of two different communication theories. The first is called Social Information Processing Theory which talks about computer mediated communication where people are more "comfortable" to speak their mind when they are on the internet or not face to face. The second is Cognitive Dissonance Theory. This one talks about how people don't like dissonance so they expose themselves to whatever creates the least dissonance in their lives. I love watching your videos and I love the way you analyze everything like an engineer. There are reasons for everything, including non-verbals. This is one of the main reasons i picked a second major so vastly different from Engineering. Thanks for explaining how everyone can communicate effectively, even with people that they might not know or agree with!!!!

I agreed with everything you said except for one thing: "the most powerful person in the world".  It doesn't matter who is president so it isn't that I don't like Obama or prefer someone else.  It is the notion that the president is some sort of dictator and that as an individual holds power over people.  Power over people is the only form of true power.  Obama occupies the highest position in our government but he himself does not have power, the office he holds does and only because we allow it.  Even though I am a proud American just as I know you are I also have an issue with the idea that you believe the sitting president to be the "most powerful person in the world" as if the US and our leader was supreme over all others.  I do see our nation as the most powerful militarily and also very influential but to say it like you did is a bit inflammatory.  There is no greater country in the world I would rather be in but just as you talk about respect for the president you should also have respect for the rest of the world.  Having said that you do an excellent show and I look forward to seeing more.

@6:20 ish... Interested is interesting... That is the single greatest piece of advice i've ever been given when it comes to social interactions. If you show a sincere interest in what a person is communicating, they will show more interest sharing it. That is most easily translated through your body language, looking at them in the eye (not more than an appropriate amount, and don't forget to blink every once in a while) nodding appropriately, agreeing appropriately, thinking of a relatively simple question to ask that demonstrates you are listening and to gain a clear picture, or in some cases, to steer the topic of conversation in another direction entirely.

I think polarisation is largely the fault of social media. Prior to social media, there wasn't as much demographic feedback available to traditional media outlets, like television and print news. As such, they would cast a broader net. They would have a political tilt one way or another, but the only people they would alienate would be those on the extreme of the other side, already. Print and television media wouldn't really repel the center very strongly. Whether we wanted it or not, we were constantly exposed to opposing view points, because we were passive targets of media. Now, with social networks, we're active curators of our media. We select what aligns with us. In turn, this makes available a trove of demographic data to traditional media providers. As people surround themselves in an affirmative chorus, the media outlets must trend out toward the extremes to keep up with the shifting demographic, lest they be seen as outdated, irrelevant, or worse, in opposition to the views they seek to market to. While the media helps reinforce our ideas, the sad fact is, Fox News wasn't far enough to the right for its audience, since the advent of social media. We no longer need the nightly news to tell us what to think. We do that in our affirmative choruses. We now tell the news what to tell us.

I haven't watched the entire thing yet, but I just hit 5 minutes where you discussed political polarization and how it is becoming so divergent. No negative feedback means no desire to drift towards middle ground.

My brain immediately went to the rise of online media, especially entities like Google and Facebook, which are known to tailor what shows up in your search results and news feed based on your user profile, and the things you have searched/clicked in the past. It's kind of nice to see less of the stuff that doesn't interest us, or doesn't align with our views, but at the same time, we are missing out on all that negative feedback which would put us closer to the middle of the spectrum, in all categories, not just political alignment.

Maybe we wouldn't be so divided if we realize that president , astronaut or whatever are people like us.  They are extremely well  suited for the situation they find themselves and frequently have honed their skills to be the best at what they do but they are still people like us. All of us, including these successful individuals, are also are moved by "secondary gains" and that is normal.  But deep down inside we are very similar. Destin, thank you so much for addressing the issue of polarization. It's jogged my memory about a point linking what you said about the media and my (albeit limited) experience with the American education system.  As someone who grew up with a British-style education system and took the SAT in the middle of my IB diploma a few years ago, it was immediately apparent to me how the one-dimensional style of writing that is encouraged in the SAT's essay questions is (perhaps accidentally) teaching the wrong values to far too many young people in the American education system, both domestic and international. I was taught to only argue one point per essay, rather than the minimum "2 points for & 1 point against" format typically seen in most Baccalaureate exams/essays in Europe.  The erosion of reasonable discussion in modern times seems, at least from my perspective, to be a product of many different facets of society including education and entertainment media as well as the "mainstream news", because in reality few people agree on every issue, yet it is useful for those in power to influence the average Joe and Jane to categorize those who disagree with them on a select few points (sexual orientation, religion, economic stance, WHATEVER), and pit otherwise good people against one another.

This video just goes to show how a lot of the most important lessons in life are taught to you when you are in kindergarten: Be respectful and listen.

I think a likely reason as to why there's such polarization in peoples views is due to how we serve data on the Internet. We try to recommend things which fall within what we think that person wants to hear/read/see, because that's what gets them using one service over another (for example, if Netflix only recommended movies you disliked, you wouldn't use it and would likely go to their competitor (especially if said competitor only recommended movies you like)).

And while such a system is great for entertainment, it's not so great for news, facts, and debates (as it makes it such that you might not even know an opposing view exists).

That being said, when it comes to social or political issues I think YouTube tends to recommend videos of views that go against mine. But that's because if I watch videos on said subject I'm more likely to watch the video which opposes my views. And while I often strongly disagree with what these people are saying I still try to understand why they think how they do.

As for a solution to the issue really all I can think of is better educating students to look for and understand the opposing arguments. When I was in school we weren't taught very well as to the reason to look into opposing arguments, we were simply told "you have to show both sides". When the reality is you need to understand why the opposing view exists in the first place, and then you need to understand why your view exists. Then you need to address all the points the opposing view makes; and the only way to do that is to fully understand them. So most often what would happen in school is people would just state what the opposing views are but not really expand upon them or prove their own view compared to the opposing view. There's also another very large issue in that schools punish you for being wrong. Meaning that people are sort of trained to hold onto their arguments far more strongly in debate even if they themselves know they can't back it up due to a fear of being proven wrong (and of course there's also the other issue as to how we go about debates; we often put the other person into a defensive mindset in which case they pretty much will not understand your point of view because they're too busy trying to defend theirs).

Another potential solution would be to make a news source that isn't biased. One of the big problems is how the source of a lot of peoples information is essentially saying "the other view is wrong they're stupid" and simply discrediting them and shrugging them off, being unwilling to hear the argument. When in reality it's rare (or even simply non-existent) that any view is right or wrong.

I myself tend to avoid debates/arguments due to the fact people are often unwilling to consider the other view. Although on occasion I do participate in debates but it's very rare (and it's only if I understand both sides of the argument). One debate I'm happy to join in on is the whole privacy debate, as I understand the reasons for and against quite well, even though I feel very strongly about one side of the argument.

Although debates are sort of null these days as most people won't change their views after a debate, so it's kind of pointless. That does depend on who you debate with though, and what you debate on. As certain topics are too polarizing, whereas others there's more of a common ground; which is a much nicer place to be as it's more possible to get things done through debate. Whereas if you're so polarized you're unlikely to change your view and the opposition is unlikely to change their view (as the views are just too far apart).


I really do think that the way things are going is quite dangerous, as I've heard of instances of colleges and universities simply not allowing someone to speak due to having an opposing view (as the students protested it due to disagreeing with their view). College and university is the absolute last place this should ever happen, but instead, it seems to be the first place it's happening. Which is quite concerning.

I really liked the feedback loop analogy that you used. And even if it is, as you said, math and not political science, it inspired a bunch of philosophers and political scientists to really think about how we interact with the world around us. Cybernetics and Systems Theory are two particularly prevalent paradigms that have positive and negative feedback as critical elements. It's really cool stuff!

It's important to note that these feedback loops are not just a product of our fractured media environment, but also come about from our desire to embrace cognitive ease and avoid dissonance. Facing dissonant information and allowing yourself to objectively consider its merits and drawbacks (without doing so to just provide yourself with additional ammunition to shoot down future arguments) is tough when ideological frames are so persistent in our minds and society. I speak both as a graduate student in Political Behavior and as someone who had to retrain his brain to give partisan ideas a fair shot. So I really admire individuals like you who are so earnest to fairly consider various viewpoints while being so infectiously positive.

Great video. We Americans need to recalibrate our vitriolic output. It's so rarely used in proportion to the perceived transgression that we force ourselves to form irrational conclusions to make up the difference. Contrary to what certain news outlets tell us, slopes aren't always slippery, association doesn't always imply guilt, our emotions aren't meant be appealed to, and ad hominem attacks aren't our most powerful reasoning tool.

It's not wrong to be angry sometimes. It's not improper to sometimes be hyperbolic either. But to be both at the same time impairs our ability to be reasonable people. When both anger and hyperbole are broadcast to the masses, it becomes downright dangerous.

I believe that the polarization, political or otherwise, is mainly due to the fact that most of our information comes from online sources these days. Due to the various algorithms that "suggest" articles/videos based on what we already agree to, the positive/negative feedback ratio gets skewed. I am sure that this has probably been covered elsewhere either on yt, or in the comments.

Maybe what we need is a way to have an "off" button to these algorithms and obtain information on any and all topics without any bias, including biases arising from the personal history of the user/demographic.

Hi Destin! I think you did a wonderful job. It was such a refreshing interview to watch. I was one of the extreme right winged person that you mentioned in your video. I live in a republican state and most everyone around me are hunters and drive big trucks. Since this is what I grew up with, it ended up being all I knew. The older I got, and the more I learned and realized that my views are no longer the same as the other people in my state. I still thought of myself as a republican because...well, that's all I knew.

Science, cosmology, growing together as a human race, and how we can move forward together, that's important to me. The day I heard about President Obama's veto for the Keystone XL bill, I started to take time to listen more to what he had to say. The more I listened without bias, the more I realized that we share some of the same views. I mean, how can that be? I'm 100% full blown republican. That was my turning point.

I feel that it's very important for everyone to learn about both sides without bias and to think about why you feel certain way about certain issues. I know this is hard because we tend to take these matters so personally, but I feel that it's the best way to understand yourself and to gain more rounded knowledge. There are not only two sides to every story (sorry Paul Harvey), I feel that there are many sides. Destin, I am glad that you went into the interview with an open mind and with great professionalism, it was a pleasure to watch it.

When you attack someone (both physically and mentally), or go at your differences with a forceful and aggressive manner, they are much more likely to fend back and defend their case really strongly. The only way this method will win is if you are so strong or so offensive in your efforts, that you totally crush them, and tear them apart.
BUT
If you go at them with a passive, or welcoming approach, they most-likely will be just as welcoming to you. They will be more accepting of your conversation and maybe even your views. And if your argument is the better side, you will have just as good of a chance of convincing them and whatnot.

The American political spectrum is considered different from the rest of the world and yet it actually isn't. What is considered to be the center of the political spectrum in Europe is considered extremist in the US (i.e. Bernie Sanders) even though polls show centrist polcies is what the majority of the American people want.

This makes people think that the extreme right (i.e. Tea Party) is representative of half the population even though the truth is it isn't. There are various reasons for this like gerrymandering and the electoral college as well as money and politics and the failure of young people to vote.

What a great interview. I learned 2 things, one of which I acted upon immediately, and a second which I'd like some help to act upon.

Ok, so the first (and this was from the first interview, not the smarter every day interview, so apologies for that!), but I was reminded how important recognition is, and I've immediately implemented some actions in my team to meaningfully incentivise certain behaviours I consider crucial to our business (I'm a scientist) that I hadn't thought to do before, so thanks to the first interviewer for that!

Secondly, the discussion about increasing polarisation, and the need to ensure we listen and are aware of the other side's arguments, I feel is a crucial failing of modern society, and one I think new media, with its subscriptions, likes, tailored content etc, while making content more widely available, risks exacerbating. So, my question to the followers of Smarter Every Day is: as a left-leaning European, but with a genuine interest in US politics (having just spent the last 5 years living there, but now back in Europe), I tend to watch The Young Turk, listen to podcasts by people like Sam Harris, follow politicians like Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, and watch comedy shows like the Nightly Show and the Daily Show. So, I'm as guilty as anyone of having my biases fed by people I already agree with. I don't agree with everything from any of these, but I find them interesting because I think they each make a genuine effort to retain balance and rationality, but they're clearly from a left-wing perspective. However, the answer isn't to start watching Fox News, or listening to Rush Limbaugh or Alex Jones. My question is this: who, or the right side, would I watch/listen to on youtube/podcasts, that would give me a meaningful balance, and offer me a thoughtful and rationale opinion, that would challenge my own? Who is the Cenk Ugur or Sam Harris of the right? This is an honest question, and not intended to be sarcastic. I'm sure there are plenty out there, and I'd like to be more aware, so I'd appreciate any suggestions.

Destin: I enjoy your channel, Smarter Everyday. Because I love your work, and respect the information you provide us, I believe your facts to be based in truth. I want to suggest two lines of inquiry about what you found out about the president.

1. Did the President really write the books you read, and was the information presented factual? As an offshoot to question number one, why did the President never write any articles or op eds when he was the editor of the Harvard Law Review?

2, Is this President an habitual liar. Take any of the president's claims about Gun Show Loopholes, his claims about Global Warming and his State of The Union etc. I use a site FactCheck.org to do my research.

I do not claim that the president has either of the two defects implied or suggested in 1 and 2. But it is important to know without doubt you have the answers to questions 1 and 2.
